docs.title: 👋 Welcome to Ping Check!
docs.text:
Ping Check is a lightweight Rust-based tool for monitoring the reachability of IP addresses using system-level ping.

Whether you're: - A sysadmin needing to monitor network nodes, - A developer testing connectivity in distributed systems, - Or just curious about which devices on your network are alive,

This tool helps you track availability in real time from the terminal with minimal setup.

docs.title: 🚀 Getting Started
docs.text:
To begin using Ping Check:

  1. Clone the repository and enter the folder
  2. Create a file named ips.txt with the list of IP addresses you want to monitor
  3. Run the program using Cargo

You'll immediately start seeing updates on which IPs are reachable (🟢) and which are not (🔴), refreshed every 5 seconds.

docs.title: ❤️ Contributing
docs.text:
Pull requests and issues are welcome! If you have suggestions for improvements, feel free to open an issue or fork the project.

Happy pinging!

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Ping Check is a command-line utility written in Rust to monitor the network reachability of a list of IP addresses using the ping command.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Rust toolchain (https://www.rust-lang.org/tools/install)
  • Internet access or local IPs to monitor

docs.title: Step 1: Prepare ips.txt
docs.text:
Create a file named ips.txt in the root directory of the project. Add one IP address per line, for example:

8.8.8.8
1.1.1.1
192.168.0.1

docs.title: Step 2: Run the program
docs.text:
Use Cargo to run the program:

cargo run --release

The application will: - Spawn a thread for each IP - Continuously send one ping every 5 seconds - Print the result as either "reachable" (🟢) or "unreachable" (🔴)

docs.title: Platform Notes
docs.text:
• On Windows, the program uses ping -n 1.
  • On Linux/macOS, it uses ping -c 1.

docs.title: Stopping the Program
docs.text: Since the program loops indefinitely, use Ctrl+C to terminate.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Ensure the IPs in ips.txt are valid and reachable.
  • Firewall rules or ICMP blocking might affect ping results.
  • On Linux/macOS, you may need permission to use ping (setuid or run with sudo).

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Threads are unbounded — large IP lists may exhaust system resources.
  • No timeout or UI. You can extend the app to add logging or an interactive dashboard.
